00040 #ifndef _physeventmanager_h
00041 #define _physeventmanager_h
00042 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00043 //This will capture all event and store them for easy dispatching.
00044 //There will be an instance of this class in the physworld.
00045 ///////////////////////////////////////
00046 
00047 #include <list>
00048 #include <queue>
00049 
00050 using namespace std;
00051 
00052 #include "physevent.h"
00053 #include "physeventrendertime.h"
00054 #include "physeventuserinput.h"
00055 #include "eventquit.h"
00056 
00057 
00058 class PhysWorld;
00059 
00060 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00061 /// @class PhysEventManager
00062 /// @headerfile physeventmanager.h
00063 /// @brief This is a container for Events and facilitates the transfer of data.
00064 /// @details The Event Manager Exists to passed important information about
00065 /// Gamestate from where it is generated to where it is needed. It is the Game
00066 /// Developers option whether they want to grab events directly using the get
00067 /// functions that have filters, or if they want to get all the events at once
00068 /// from a central location and dispatch form there. \n
00069 /// Since all User input comes in the form of events, this is also where user
00070 /// input Polling and optional input sources like Joysticks are controlled
00071 /// from. \n
00072 /// All of these event are stored in an internal Queue and order is preserved.
00073 /// So the First item In will be the First Out (FIFO). This is not strictly a
00074 /// FIFO buffer, there are a number of functions for getting of managing
00075 /// specific kinds of events. Generally these 'Filtered' management functions
00076 /// Still return the first of those kinds of event.
00077 /// @warning Delete pointers you get from this. Anything can create events and
00078 /// Put them here, and anything can get them out, This means the simple way to
00079 /// not cause memory leaks is to have the routines extracting the events delete
00080 /// the events.
00081 /// @warning Currently this is not thread safe, even though it should be.
00082 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00083 class PhysEventManager
00084 {
00085         private:
00086         //The Default Physics worlds that this Eventmanager is expected to interact with
00087         PhysWorld* ParentWorld;
00088 
00089         //The Queue that all the events get stored in
00090                 list<PhysEvent*> EventQueue;
00091 
00092         //Checks for quit messages and adds them to the queue
00093         void UpdateQuitEvents();
00094 
00095         // A list of the Mouse buttons being watched
00096         vector<int> WatchMouseKeys;
00097 
00098         //a List of the Keyboard keys being watch
00099         vector<MetaCode::InputCode> WatchKeyboardKeys;
00100 
00101         //These are use to decide if mouse location should be polled.
00102         bool PollMouseHor;
00103         bool PollMouseVert;
00104 
00105         //These does the heavy lifting during the polling operation
00106         //All of these poll the input subsystem and add MetaCodes to the vector they are passed.
00107         void PollKeyboard(vector<MetaCode> &CodeBag);
00108         void PollMouseButtons(vector<MetaCode> &CodeBag);
00109         void PollMouseLocation(vector<MetaCode> &CodeBag);
00110 
00111         //SDL event specific Items
00112                 //This function will get all the events from SDL and Sort them into one of two Queues
00113                 void PreProcessSDLEvents();
00114         queue<RawEvent*> SDL_WmEvents;
00115         queue<RawEvent*> SDL_UserInputEvents;
00116 
00117         public:
00118         /// @todo TODO build a deconstructor that deletes all the events still int the queue
00119 
00120         /// @brief Default constructor
00121         /// @param ParentWorld_ A pointer to the world that this physworld is working with Primarily
00122         /// @details This creates an empty PhysEventManger
00123                 PhysEventManager(PhysWorld* ParentWorld_);
00124 
00125         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00126         // Management functions - Work with all events
00127         ///////////////////////////////////////
00128         /// @brief Gets a count of events
00129         /// @details This returns a total count of all events stored in this PhysEventManager.
00130                 /// @return This returns an unsigned integer with the amount of of total events
00131         unsigned int GetRemainingEventCount();
00132 
00133         /// @brief Return a pointer to the Next event
00134         /// @details This returns a pointer to the next PhysEvent. It is advisable to use this for performance reasons
00135         /// because it runs in constant time. However it does not return a specific kind of event, and must be cast
00136         /// in order to use the true content. This returns a pointer to 0 if there are no events in the que.
00137         /// @return A pointer to a PhysEvent, that still needs to be removed from the event manager and deleted.
00138                 PhysEvent* GetNextEvent();
00139 
00140         /// @brief Return a pointer to the Next event, and removes the Event from storage
00141         /// @details This functions just like GetNextEvent , except that it also removes the item from the internal storage
00142         /// of the PhysEventManager. This returns a pointer to 0 if there are no events in the que.
00143         /// @return A pointer to a PhysEvent, that will need to be deleted once it has been used.
00144         PhysEvent* PopNextEvent();
00145 
00146         /// @brief Removes an Event From the que without looking at it.
00147         /// @details This together with GetNextEvent() are the same as call PopNextEvent().
00148         /// @warning If you did not call GetNextEvent() and haven't deleted or stored, or somehow dealt with this pointer, then this is a memory leak.
00149         /// Don't use this unless you are certain you have taken care of the pointer appropriately
00150         /// @exception This can throw any STL exception a que could. Any with likely throw some kind of except if called when there are no Events in the Que.
00151         void RemoveNextEvent();
00152 
00153         /// @brief Adds an event of any kind to the end of the Event Queue
00154         /// @param EventToAdd This is a pointer to an Event.
00155         /// @details This adds the existing event to the Queue. Be careful this is not delete, and does not go out of scope. Deleting the Event is now the
00156         /// responsibilty of the code that pulls it out of Event Manager.
00157         void AddEvent(PhysEvent* EventToAdd);
00158 
00159         void UpdateEvents();
00160         void UpdateSystemEvents();
00161         void UpdateUserInputEvents();
00162 
00163         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00164         // Filtered management functions - RenderTime Events
00165         ///////////////////////////////////////
00166         /// @brief Returns a pointer to the Next Rendertime event
00167         /// @details This Filtered event management function returns a pointer to the next Rendertime event. It is inadvisable to use
00168         /// this for performance reasons becuase it runs in linear time relative to the amount of events. However, it will return an immediately
00169         /// usable pointer for case where an extreme level of performance is not required. This returns a pointer to 0 if there are no rendertime
00170         /// events in the que.
00171         /// @return A pointer to a PhysEventRenderTime, that still needs to be removed from the event manager and deleted.
00172                 PhysEventRenderTime* GetNextRenderTimeEvent();
00173 
00174         /// @brief Returns a pointer to the Next Rendertime event and removes it from the Que
00175         /// @details This Filtered event management function returns a pointer to the next Rendertime event. It is inadvisable to use
00176         /// this for performance reasons becuase it runs in linear time relative to the amount of events. However, it will return an immediately
00177         /// usable pointer for case where an extreme level of performance is not required. This returns a pointer to 0 if there are no rendertime
00178         /// events in the que. This also removes the returned pointer form the Que.
00179         /// @return A pointer to a PhysEventRenderTime, that still needs to be removed from the event manager and deleted.
00180                 PhysEventRenderTime* PopNextRenderTimeEvent();
00181 
00182                 /// @brief Removes the First Rendertime Event From the que without looking at it.
00183         /// @details This together with GetNextRenderTimeEvent() are the pretty much same as call PopNextRenderTimeEvent().
00184         /// @warning If you did not call GetNextRenderTimeEvent() and haven't deleted or stored, or somehow dealt with this pointer, then this is a memory leak.
00185         /// Don't use this unless you are certain you have taken care of the pointer appropriately
00186         /// @exception This can throw any STL exception a queue could. And with likely throw some kind of except if called when there are no Events in the Que.
00187         void RemoveNextRenderTimeEvent();
00188 
00189         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00190         // Filtered management functions - User Input Events
00191         ///////////////////////////////////////
00192         /// @brief Returns a pointer to the Next User Input event
00193         /// @details This Filtered event management function returns a pointer to the next User Input event. It is inadvisable to use
00194         /// this for performance reasons becuase it runs in linear time relative to the amount of events. However, it will return an immediately
00195         /// usable pointer for case where an extreme level of performance is not required. This returns a pointer to 0 if there are no User Input
00196         /// events in the que.
00197         /// @return A pointer to a PhysEventUserInput, that still needs to be removed from the event manager and deleted.
00198         PhysEventUserInput* GetNextUserInputEvent();
00199 
00200         /// @brief Returns a pointer to the Next User Input event and removes it from the Que
00201         /// @details This Filtered event management function returns a pointer to the next User Input event. It is inadvisable to use
00202         /// this for performance reasons becuase it runs in linear time relative to the amount of events. However, it will return an immediately
00203         /// usable pointer for case where an extreme level of performance is not required. This returns a pointer to 0 if there are no User Input
00204         /// events in the que. This also removes the returned pointer form the Que.
00205         /// @return A pointer to a PhysEventUserInput, that still needs to be removed from the event manager and deleted.
00206         PhysEventUserInput* PopNextUserInputEvent();
00207 
00208         /// @brief Removes the First User Input Event From the que without looking at it.
00209         /// @details This together with GetNextUserInputEvent() are the pretty much same as call PopNextUserInputEvent().
00210         /// @warning If you did not call GetNextUserInputEvent() and haven't deleted or stored, or somehow dealt with this pointer, then this is a memory leak.
00211         /// Don't use this unless you are certain you have taken care of the pointer appropriately
00212         /// @exception This can throw any STL exception a queue could. And with likely throw some kind of except if called when there are no Events in the Que.
00213         void RemoveNextUserInputEvent();
00214 
00215         EventQuit* GetNextQuitEvent();
00216         EventQuit* PopNextQuitEvent();
00217         void RemoveNextQuitEvent();
00218 
00219         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00220         // Filtered management functions - You choose YAYYYY!!!
00221         ///////////////////////////////////////
00222         /// @brief Returns a pointer to the Next kind event of the Specified type
00223         /// @param SpecificType This is a PhysEvent::EventType that defines the type you want this to work with
00224         /// @details This and the other NextSpecificEvent functions are the core of the Event Filtering System. In general the other filtering
00225         /// functions call one of these and does very little work on their own. \n This performs a linear search starting with the oldest (first entered
00226         /// Events) and simply checks if it the of the correct type. Then this returns a pointer to the next event of the specified type, or returns
00227         /// a pointer to 0 if there are none of the correct pointers in the Que. It is inadvisable to use
00228         /// this for performance reasons becuase it runs in linear time relative to the amount of events.
00229         /// @return A pointer to a PhysEventUserInput, that still needs to be removed from the event manager and deleted.
00230         PhysEvent* GetNextSpecificEvent(PhysEvent::EventType SpecificType);
00231 
00232         /// @brief Returns a pointer to the Next kind event of the Specified type, and removes it from the Que
00233         /// @param SpecificType This is a PhysEvent::EventType that defines the type you want this to work with
00234         /// @details This is just like GetNextSpecificEvent(PhysEvent::EventType SpecificType) but it also removes the item from the Que.
00235         /// @return A pointer to a PhysEventUserInput, that still needs to be removed from the event manager and deleted.
00236         PhysEvent* PopNextSpecificEvent(PhysEvent::EventType SpecificType);
00237 
00238         /// @brief Returns a pointer to the Next kind event of the Specified type, and removes it from the Que
00239         /// @param SpecificType This is a PhysEvent::EventType that defines the type you want this to work with
00240         /// @details This is just like PopNextSpecificEvent(PhysEvent::EventType SpecificType) but exept it doesn't bother with any of the needed
00241         /// structure involved with returning data, and just removes the specific evetn from the Que.
00242         /// @warning If you did not call GetNextSpecificEvent(PhysEvent::EventType SpecificType) and haven't deleted or stored, or somehow dealt with
00243         /// this pointer, then this is a memory leak. Don't use this unless you are certain you have taken care of the pointer appropriately.
00244         /// @exception This can throw any STL exception a queue could. And with likely throw some kind of except if called when there are no Events in the Que.
00245         void RemoveNextSpecificEvent(PhysEvent::EventType SpecificType);
00246 
00247         /// @brief Generates extra events each iteration of the main loop, based on user input polling
00248         /// @param InputToTryPolling This accepts a MetaCode and will try to watch for occurences like this one
00249         /// @details This will trigger the input system to generate an event (or add to an exiting event) when polling for the given kind of event. Each
00250         /// Iteration of the main loop there will be a PhysEventUserInput that created. That Event will Include all the normal metacodes for user input
00251         /// that happened, and it will also have a meta code for each time this function was called. The added metacode may be partialky ignored, the
00252         /// Metavalue is almost always ignored, and in a situation where the can only be one of a given input on a system, the ID is ignore and 0 is assumed.
00253         /// @exception "Unsupported Polling Check on this Platform" When the metacode passed cannot be polled on this platform
00254         void AddPollingCheck(const MetaCode &InputToTryPolling);
00255 
00256         /// @brief Removes Events from the list(s) of what needs to be polled
00257         /// @param InputToStopPolling This accepts a MetaCode and will try to Remove Watches like this one
00258         /// @details This will remove any check for polling that share the same inputcode and ID. This
00259         /// @exception "Polling check not present" Is thrown
00260         void RemovePollingCheck(const MetaCode &InputToStopPolling);
00261 
00262         /// @brief This activates the polling routines of the user input subsystems
00263         /// @details This checks the current state of user input devices that have been added by AddPollingCheck(const MetaCode &InputToTryPolling).
00264         /// This is called automatically by main loop processing, but there is no harm in calling it several times.
00265         /// @return This returns a pointer to a PhysEventUserInput that contains the desired metacodes
00266         PhysEventUserInput* PollForUserInputEvents();
00267 };
00268 
00269 #endif
